The warnings signs have nudged higher compared to January, when 3.5 signals were indicating sell.

“The checklist told us to hold our nerve in 2011-12. It told us to do the same during sharp corrections in August 2015 and early 2016,” Citi said.

The model isn’t a predictor of events, but rather a guide of what to do if stocks fall. And “right now, it is telling us to keep buying the dips”.

Citi said to keep an eye on two factors in the checklist: the spread between US 2-year and 10-year government bonds (know as the yield curve) and credit spreads on high-grade US corporate bonds.

A flat yield curve has often been a good predictor of recessions, although this week’s spike in yields has seen the 2-10 spread widen out to 30 basis points as 10-year yields rose more sharply.

But if the yield curve does flatten and the spread between high-grade corporate bonds and US treasuries climbs above 175 basis points (from the current level of 109 basis points), “we would be much more worried about the future direction of global equities”, Citi said.

So factoring those risks into account, are markets late-cycle or end-cycle?

“Current opinion is deeply divided,” Citi said. “The guidance from prior bear markets is inconclusive. Many metrics already look stretched, but there is no ‘magic level’ at which markets consistently roll over.”

Ultimately, Citi said profit growth remains strong and interest rates in major developed economies are still low. As a result, the bank said there’s “still room to run” for equities.

The bank’s analysts are overweight US and UK stocks, and underweight Japan and Australia.

“We are not bearish but think that Australian equities will lag,” Citi said.

https://www.investors.com/news/technology/saas-stocks-cloud-stocks/
SaaS Stocks To Buy And Watch: These Top Software Firms Thrive As Cloud Stocks

Whether you're looking for the best cloud stocks or the top software companies to own, invariably the search leads to software-as-a-service, or SaaS. The reason is SaaS stocks post the best revenue growth among enterprise software companies.




SaaS stocks also are involved in the most mergers and acquisitions in the software sector. And, SaaS stocks trade at the highest multiples.

The customers of SaaS vendors purchase renewable subscriptions, rather than one-time, perpetual software licenses. Customers receive automatic software updates via the web.

The IBD 50 roster of fast-growing companies now includes Adobe Systems (ADBE). Like Microsoft (MSFT), Adobe has moved to selling subscriptions from a licensing business model.


ServiceNow (NOW), which sells software for information technology management, also belongs in the IBD 50.

SaaS Stocks Span Marketing, Security, Human Resources

SaaS stocks span marketing with the likes of Salesforce.com (CRM), HubSpot (HUBS) and Zendesk (ZEN). There's also human resources stock such as Workday (WDAY), Paycom Software (PAYC), Ultimate Software (ULTI) and Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD)).

In communications software, there's Twilio (TWLO), and in cybersecurity you'll find Zscaler (ZS), Proofpoint (PFPT) and FireEye (FEYE). And there's information technology with ServiceNow, Atlassian (TEAM) and New Relic (NEWR), among other sectors.

Some SaaS stocks focus on industry verticals such as home security firm Alarm Holdings (ALRM); medical software maker Veeva Systems (VEEV) and rental housing specialist Real Page (RP).

SaaS Stocks Turn Into Cloud Stocks

SaaS stocks are now viewed by many analysts as cloud computing stocks. The two technologies evolved separately, though.

SaaS came first. SaaS pioneer Salesforce.com was started in 1999. Cloud software pioneer Amazon Web Services, founded in 2006, didn't hit a billion dollars in sales until 2012.

Cloud customers pay-as-they-go, leasing computing resources by the minute or hour via the web. That's not a subscription model. But SaaS also is an on-demand service, making it cloudlike.

Bottom line: marketing by software companies is blurring the line between SaaS stocks and cloud stocks.

https://ark-invest.com/research/market-volatility


Addressing Concerns During Periods of Market Volatility


Given the recent move in interest rates, intensified trade tensions, and increased market volatility, we would like to share some of our thoughts.

We presented two charts during our monthly mARKet update webinar this past week that offer some perspective.


The chart above suggests that Fed policy is not tight. Before or during past crises, the Fed has ignored signals from the three-month Treasury Bill Rate and tightened too much or eased too late and too little, allowing the three-month Treasury Bill Rate to drop 20 basis points (bps) below the Fed funds rate. Today, the Fed seems to be following the economy in setting policy, not trying to get ahead of it or to cut it off. Indeed, the Treasury Bill Rate is nearly 20 basis points above the Fed funds rate, higher than it has been in nearly 25 crisis-prone years.

The chart below suggests that, even though equities have not been in a bear market for nearly ten years, funds have not followed the market up. While cumulative bond inflows have totaled roughly $2 trillion, equity flows have been negative since 2008. When, we wonder, will the reallocation from bonds back to equities begin?

quote.msg:
https://ark-invest.com/research/market-volatility


Addressing Concerns During Periods of Market Volatility


Given the recent move in interest rates, intensified trade tensions, and increased market volatility, we would like to share some of our thoughts.

We presented two charts during our monthly mARKet update webinar this past week that offer some perspective.


The chart above suggests that Fed policy is not tight. Before or during past crises, the Fed has ignored signals from the three-month Treasury Bill Rate and tightened too much or eased too late and too little, allowing the three-month Treasury Bill Rate to drop 20 basis points (bps) below the Fed funds rate. Today, the Fed seems to be following the economy in setting policy, not trying to get ahead of it or to cut it off. Indeed, the Treasury Bill Rate is nearly 20 basis points above the Fed funds rate, higher than it has been in nearly 25 crisis-prone years.

The chart below suggests that, even though equities have not been in a bear market for nearly ten years, funds have not followed the market up. While cumulative bond inflows have totaled roughly $2 trillion, equity flows have been negative since 2008. When, we wonder, will the reallocation from bonds back to equities begin?

replies.msg:
Another concern is that the yield curve has been flattening, something we have been anticipating thanks to strong real GDP growth – pushing short term interest rates up – as inflation surprises on the low side of expectations thanks to technologically enabled innovation – holding long term interest rates down. We would not be surprised to see the yield curve invert in the “deflationary boom” that we are anticipating during the next few years, much like it did in the late 1800s/early 1900s, the last period during which multiple innovation platforms were evolving at the same time. During the past 50 years, inverted yield curves have been associated with recessions, so understandably investors are concerned. Based on our research, we are not concerned.
As for trade tensions, we believe that they are diminishing as the US now has deals with Mexico and Canada, our two largest trading partners, as well as South Korea, and our talks with Japan and Europe seem to be making progress. As a result, China has become somewhat isolated. During NikkoAM’s FOREWARD conference in Singapore in August, we learned that China may be willing to buy more US goods and to grant technology companies intellectual property rights but is not willing to limit subsidies to SOEs (state owned enterprises). If so, given my experience and view of the current US administration’s position, I believe that we not only will have a deal but that it will include widespread tariff reductions as well. Another (tariff) tax cut, global in scale, would be very bullish.

As it relates to the technology sector, my experience during periods of uncertainty is that innovative companies gain significant share in tumultuous times. Their shares get hit disproportionately in the early stages of a correction because they tend not to be big index players, but they recover much faster than many of the value traps that populate the traditional indexes in which investors seek safety. A good example in 2008-10 was Salesforce.com (CRM) which was not in most broad-based indexes. Chief Technology Officers at that time were told to cut their budgets 20-30% so they were forced to do things differently: they moved away from the enterprise license/maintenance model to “pay as you go”, the software as a service model. While tech spending dropped 20%+, CRM’s worst quarter for revenue growth was +20%!1 Its stock got hit hard in the early phase of the market’s decline, but it came out flying. Truth does win out once the emotional reaction (and the race back to benchmarks) ends.

During periods of market volatility, investors should concentrate their portfolios toward their highest conviction names, as “babies are thrown out with the bath water”. Investors should pick up the “babies”.

3 month t-bill rate 大過fed fund rate ＝Fed is not tight


Addressing Concerns During Periods of Market Volatility
October 17, 2018|by Catherine Wood, ARK Invest CEO|Market Insights, Review
Tags: economics, market review, yield curve
Given the recent move in interest rates, intensified trade tensions, and increased market volatility, we would like to share some of our thoughts.

We presented two charts during our monthly mARKet update webinar this past week that offer some perspective.


The chart above suggests that Fed policy is not tight. Before or during past crises, the Fed has ignored signals from the three-month Treasury Bill Rate and tightened too much or eased too late and too little, allowing the three-month Treasury Bill Rate to drop 20 basis points (bps) below the Fed funds rate. Today, the Fed seems to be following the economy in setting policy, not trying to get ahead of it or to cut it off. Indeed, the Treasury Bill Rate is nearly 20 basis points above the Fed funds rate, higher than it has been in nearly 25 crisis-prone years.
The chart below suggests that, even though equities have not been in a bear market for nearly ten years, funds have not followed the market up. While cumulative bond inflows have totaled roughly $2 trillion, equity flows have been negative since 2008. When, we wonder, will the reallocation from bonds back to equities begin?


Another concern is that the yield curve has been flattening, something we have been anticipating thanks to strong real GDP growth – pushing short term interest rates up – as inflation surprises on the low side of expectations thanks to technologically enabled innovation – holding long term interest rates down. We would not be surprised to see the yield curve invert in the “deflationary boom” that we are anticipating during the next few years, much like it did in the late 1800s/early 1900s, the last period during which multiple innovation platforms were evolving at the same time. During the past 50 years, inverted yield curves have been associated with recessions, so understandably investors are concerned. Based on our research, we are not concerned.

Today, the Fed seems to be following the economy in setting policy, not trying to get ahead of it or to cut it off. Indeed, the Treasury Bill Rate is nearly 20 basis points above the Fed funds rate, higher than it has been in nearly 25 crisis-prone years.
The chart below suggests that, even though equities have not been in a bear market for nearly ten years, funds have not followed the market up. While cumulative bond inflows have totaled roughly $2 trillion, equity flows have been negative since 2008. When, we wonder, will the reallocation from bonds back to equities begin?


Another concern is that the yield curve has been flattening, something we have been anticipating thanks to strong real GDP growth – pushing short term interest rates up – as inflation surprises on the low side of expectations thanks to technologically enabled innovation – holding long term interest rates down. We would not be surprised to see the yield curve invert in the “deflationary boom” that we are anticipating during the next few years, much like it did in the late 1800s/early 1900s, the last period during which multiple innovation platforms were evolving at the same time. During the past 50 years, inverted yield curves have been associated with recessions, so understandably investors are concerned. Based on our research, we are not concerned.

Addressing Concerns During Periods of Market Volatility
October 17, 2018|by Catherine Wood, ARK Invest CEO|Market Insights, Review
Tags: economics, market review, yield curve
Given the recent move in interest rates, intensified trade tensions, and increased market volatility, we would like to share some of our thoughts.

We presented two charts during our monthly mARKet update webinar this past week that offer some perspective.


The chart above suggests that Fed policy is not tight. Before or during past crises, the Fed has ignored signals from the three-month Treasury Bill Rate and tightened too much or eased too late and too little, allowing the three-month Treasury Bill Rate to drop 20 basis points (bps) below the Fed funds rate. Today, the Fed seems to be following the economy in setting policy, not trying to get ahead of it or to cut it off. Indeed, the Treasury Bill Rate is nearly 20 basis points above the Fed funds rate, higher than it has been in nearly 25 crisis-prone years.
The chart below suggests that, even though equities have not been in a bear market for nearly ten years, funds have not followed the market up. While cumulative bond inflows have totaled roughly $2 trillion, equity flows have been negative since 2008. When, we wonder, will the reallocation from bonds back to equities begin?


Another concern is that the yield curve has been flattening, something we have been anticipating thanks to strong real GDP growth – pushing short term interest rates up – as inflation surprises on the low side of expectations thanks to technologically enabled innovation – holding long term interest rates down. We would not be surprised to see the yield curve invert in the “deflationary boom” that we are anticipating during the next few years, much like it did in the late 1800s/early 1900s, the last period during which multiple innovation platforms were evolving at the same time. During the past 50 years, inverted yield curves have been associated with recessions, so understandably investors are concerned. Based on our research, we are not concerned.

This Highly Rated Pharma Giant Is More Than Just A Diabetes Player
FacebookTwitterLinkedInShare Licensing
ALLISON GATLIN11/21/2018
Investors may know Eli Lilly (LLY) as a venerable member of the Big Pharma club whose bread and butter now comes from diabetes treatments. But analysts say Lilly stock is due for a boost from the drug giant's burgeoning migraine prevention and immunology medicines.


Diabetes treatments made up 38% of Lilly's third-quarter sales. To be sure, diabetes drug Trulicity is a strong contender — spiking by more than half to account for the biggest chunk of revenue. But the best growth during the quarter came from immunology drug Taltz.

Taltz sales rocketed 74% to $263.9 million in the third quarter, making it Lilly's seventh-biggest drug. Still, SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analyst John Boris says investors don't truly understand the opportunity for Taltz and another immunology drug, Olumiant.

"We expect immunology sales to grow from $605 million in 2017 to $4.1 billion in 2022, primarily on underappreciated new indication/label expansion opportunities for Taltz and Olumiant," he said in a recent report to clients.

Lilly's Jump Into Immunology Drugs

Lilly's foray into immunology began in 2016 with the launch of Taltz. Today, Taltz can treat plaque psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. Olumiant, developed with Incyte (INCY), gained approval this year in the U.S. as a rheumatoid arthritis treatment.

SunTrust's Boris says Lilly's Taltz benefits from a split in the psoriasis market. Taltz blocks a cytokine called interleukin-17A to reduce inflammation. Its main rivals include Cosentyx, from Novartis (NVS), and Bausch Health Companies' (BHC) Siliq.

Lilly also plans to ask the Food and Drug Administration to approve Taltz as a treatment for axial spondyloarthritis, a chronic form of arthritis. This "should help drive growth," Boris said. He models $2.5 billion in 2022 sales of Taltz.

But Boris is less enthusiastic on Olumiant which has ramped up slowly — given competitive headwinds from Pfizer's (PFE) Xeljanz.

"Fortunately for Lilly, Olumiant is seeing much stronger uptake outside the U.S. — where (a smaller) 4-milligram dose is approved — particularly in Europe," Boris said. Lilly is also looking to expand Olumiant into eczema, lupus, psoriatic arthritis and alopecia.

He sees $1.4 billion in 2023 sales of Olumiant.

Soon To Top Migraine Prevention?

Lilly also is pushing deeper into treatments for neurological and pain disorders. At the crux of the two, the FDA recently approved Lilly's Emgality, a migraine prevention drug. Emgality belongs to a class of drugs that aim to block a substance called CGRP.

Partners Amgen (AMGN) and Novartis were the first to the market with Aimovig. Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) followed with Ajovy. Lilly was third to the U.S. market with Emgality, which got the green light in September.

Although it came after others, Emgality's "competitive" label could push it to the top of the migraine prevention market, SunTrust's Boris said. He notes that migraine prevention is a highly unmet medical need.

[url]https://www.investors.com/research/the-new-america/lilly-stock-migraine-prevention-diabetes-treatments/
[/url]
"We view Lilly's aggressive commercial approach as potentially enabling Emgality to secure a No. 1 share position in the class despite being third-to-market and the ongoing aggressive sampling and discounting by competitive CGRP manufacturers," he said.

Boris' estimate for Emgality sales is well above the consensus at $1.03 billion globally in 2022 vs. the broader Street view for $771 million.

Also this month, Lilly asked the FDA to approve a drug called lasmiditan as a treatment for acute migraines. Later this year, Lilly says it will ask FDA officials to approve Emgality as a preventive treatment for episodic cluster headaches.

"Headache disorders like migraine and cluster headache affect each person differently, and many patients spend years cycling through different medications to effectively diagnose and treat their symptoms," Gudarz Davar, Lilly's vice president of neurology, said in a statement.

Diabetes Treatments Going Strong

Lilly's biggest drug efforts are in diabetes and cancer treatments. In the third quarter, diabetes treatments generated almost $2.31 billion in sales. Cancer treatments brought in nearly $1.04 billion, or about 17% of total revenue.

Breast cancer treatment Verzenio has had some success despite being third into a $10 billion market for its drug class, Boris said. It competes closely with Novartis' Kisqali. He models $2 billion in 2022 sales for Verzenio.

Verzenio and other new cancer treatments will be necessary to offset the likelihood for slower sales of chemotherapy Alimta. Alimta will likely lose patent protection in 2022, Boris said. Lilly has a deep pipeline in oncology, but much of it remains in early-stage testing.

Diabetes treatments, on the other hand, continue to look robust. Earlier this month, Lilly said its diabetes treatment, Trulicity, cut down on the risk of cardiovascular death, heart attack or stroke in type 2 patients.

Boris called that study, deemed Rewind, "precedent-setting." Argus analyst David Toung said Trulicity's position "in the diabetes market has been strengthened by results from the post-approval Rewind trial."

SunTrust analyst Boris calls for diabetes treatments to generate $12.7 billion in sales in 2022, rising from $7.8 billion in 2017. This will be driven by "robust growth for Trulicity, Jardiance and Basaglar," he said.

"Lilly's diabetes business is not only Lilly's largest segment, but also its fastest and most diversified growth driver through 2022," he said.


Both Boris and Argus' Toung have buy ratings on Lilly stock. On Nov. 8, Toung lifted his price target on Lilly stock to 135 from 115.

High Ratings For Lilly Stock

Lilly stock can also claim high ratings from Investor's Business Daily. It has a Composite Rating of 98, just one point short of a perfect score. This means it performs in the top 1% of all stocks in terms of key growth metrics.

Lilly stock also has a Relative Strength Rating of 96, also out of a best-possible 99. The RS Rating tracks a stock's performance over the past 12 months. Among the broader group of Big Pharma stocks, Lilly stock is ranked third.

Lilly stock is currently forming a flat base with a buy point at 116.71. Shares fell 2.2% Wednesday to close at 112.23.

投資者可能知道禮來公司（LLY）是大型製藥俱樂部的老牌成員，其麵包和黃油現在來自糖尿病治療。但分析師表示，禮來公司的股票將來自這家藥物巨頭迅速發展的偏頭痛預防和免疫學藥物。

  
糖尿病治療佔禮來公司第三季度銷售額的38％。可以肯定的是，糖尿病藥物Trulicity是一個強有力的競爭者 - 超過一半的飆升佔據了最大的收入。但本季度最好的增長來自免疫藥物Taltz。

第三季度Taltz的銷售額飆升74％，達到2.639億美元，成為禮來公司的第七大毒品。 SunTrust Robinson Humphrey分析師John Boris表示，投資者並不真正理解Taltz和另一種免疫藥物Olumiant的機會。

“我們預計免疫學銷售額將從2017年的6.05億美元增長到2022年的41億美元，主要是因為Taltz和Olumiant的新指標/標籤擴張機會被低估，”他在最近向客戶提交的一份報告中表示。


莉莉跳進免疫學藥物

隨著Taltz的推出，Lilly在2016年開始涉足免疫學領域。今天，Taltz可以治療斑塊狀銀屑病和銀屑病關節炎。由Incyte（INCY）開發的Olumiant今年在美國獲得批准，作為類風濕性關節炎治療。

SunTrust的Boris說Lilly的Taltz受益於牛皮癬市場的分裂。 Taltz阻斷了一種名為白細胞介素-17A的細胞因子，以減少炎症。其主要競爭對手包括諾華（NVS）的Cosentyx和Bausch Health Companies（BHC）Siliq。

Lilly還計劃要求美國食品和藥物管理局批准Taltz治療軸性脊柱關節炎，這是一種慢性關節炎。鮑里斯說，這“應該有助於推動增長”。他在2022年的Taltz銷售中塑造了25億美元。

但考慮到輝瑞公司（PFE）Xeljanz的競爭逆風，鮑里斯對Olumiant的熱情不高，而Olumiant已經緩慢上升。

“對Lilly來說幸運的是，Olumiant在美國以外地區的吸收率要高得多 - 其中（較小的）4毫克劑量被批准 - 特別是在歐洲，”鮑里斯說。 Lilly還希望將Olumiant擴展為濕疹，狼瘡，銀屑病關節炎和脫髮。

他看到2023年Olumiant的銷售額為14億美元。

很快就會預防偏頭痛？

禮來公司也正在深入研究神經和疼痛疾病的治療方法。在這兩者的關鍵時刻，FDA最近批准了Lilly的Emgality，一種預防偏頭痛的藥物。 Emgality屬於一類旨在阻斷CGRP物質的藥物。

合作夥伴Amgen（AMGN）和諾華是Aimovig首次進入市場。 Teva Pharmaceutical（TEVA）緊隨其後的是Ajovy。禮來公司憑藉Emgality在美國市場排名第三，該公司於9月份獲得了綠燈。

SunTrust的Boris表示，儘管它取代了其他產品，但Emgality的“競爭”品牌可能將其推向偏頭痛預防市場的頂峰。他指出，預防偏頭痛是一項非常缺乏的醫療需求。

“我們認為禮來的積極商業方法有可能使Emgality在同類產品中獲得第一的位置，儘管它是第三個進入市場的，並且正在競爭性的CGRP製造商持續積極的抽樣和折扣，”他說。

鮑里斯對Emgality銷售額的估計遠遠高於2022年全球市場預期的10.3億美元，而街頭市場觀點為7.71億美元。

同樣在本月，禮來公司要求FDA批准一種名為lasmiditan的藥物作為治療急性偏頭痛的藥物。今年晚些時候，禮來公司表示將要求FDA官員批准Emgality作為陣發性叢集性頭痛的預防性治療方法。

“偏頭痛和叢集性頭痛等頭痛症會以不同的方式影響每個人，許多患者花費數年時間通過不同的藥物循環來有效地診斷和治療他們的症狀，”禮來公司神經病學副總裁Gudarz Davar在一份聲明中說。

糖尿病治療走強

禮來公司最大的藥物是糖尿病和癌症治療。在第三季度，糖尿病治療產生了近23.1億美元的銷售額。癌症治療帶來了近10.4億美元，約佔總收入的17％。

鮑里斯說，乳腺癌治療Verzenio取得了一些成功，儘管其藥物類別的市場排名第三，價值100億美元。它與諾華的基斯卡利密切競爭。他在2022年為Verzenio銷售20億美元。

Verzenio和其他新的癌症治療方法將有必要抵消化療Alimta銷售緩慢的可能性。鮑里斯說，Alimta可能會在2022年失去專利保護。 Lilly在腫瘤學方面擁有深厚的管道，但其中大部分仍處於早期階段的測試階段。

另一方面，糖尿病治療繼續看起來很健壯。本月早些時候，禮來公司表示，其糖尿病治療方法Trulicity減少了心血管疾病死亡，心髒病發作或中風的風險。
